title: Classic Chili with Homemade Cornbread Croutons

description: This hearty classic chili combines rich ground meats, savory beans, and bold spices simmered to perfection, topped with crunchy homemade cornbread croutons for a delightful texture contrast. Perfect for cozy dinners, this recipe delivers comforting flavors that warm the soul and impress your family or guests.
ingredients: 1 pound ground turkey or ground beef
1 pound ground turkey sausage or pork sausage
1 14 oz. can diced tomatoes with garlic, basil, and oregano
1 can kidney beans, drained and rinsed
1 can black beans, drained and rinsed
1 14 oz. can beef broth (or more for thinner chili)
1/4 teaspoon black pepper, more to taste
instructions: In a large soup pot or Dutch oven, cook the ground meat, chopped onion, and minced garlic over medium heat until the meat is fully cooked, about 10 minutes.
Drain excess meat juices if desired to keep the chili healthier.
Add the beef broth, crushed tomatoes, diced tomatoes, kidney beans, black beans, chili powder, ground cumin, salt, and black pepper to the pot. Stir well to combine.
Bring the mixture to a simmer and cook uncovered for 30 to 45 minutes, stirring occasionally, until flavors meld and chili thickens to your liking.
Adjust salt and pepper to taste before serving.
For the homemade cornbread croutons, cut leftover cornbread into large chunks.
Toss the cornbread pieces with olive oil, garlic salt, and black pepper.
Spread the cornbread chunks on a baking sheet and bake at 250-300°F (120-150°C) for about 45 minutes or until dried out and crunchy, checking occasionally to avoid burning.
Serve the chili hot, topped with cheese, sour cream, chopped onions, cornbread croutons, or hot sauce as desired.
tips: Simmer chili uncovered to thicken and concentrate flavors. Don’t skip draining the meat fat if you prefer a leaner chili. Look for bubbling and a thick consistency as a sign the chili is ready. Store leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 4 days; reheat gently to preserve texture.

structured_content.content: This Classic Chili with Homemade Cornbread Croutons is a soul-warming dish that combines savory meats, hearty beans, and rich spices simmered into a thick, flavorful stew. The crunchy cornbread croutons add a delightful sweet and crispy texture that perfectly complements the robust chili, making every bite a comforting experience.

note.content:

structured_content.content: This chili recipe has been a family favorite for years, evoking memories of cozy fall evenings and lively dinner conversations. The addition of cornbread croutons was a happy accident from leftover BBQ sides, turning a classic into something truly special and memorable.

• Main ingredient: Ground turkey or beef and sausage provide a rich, meaty base; choose fresh, high-quality meats for best flavor and texture.
  • Key seasonings/flavoring agents: Chili powder and cumin bring warmth and depth; look for fresh spices for maximum aroma.
  • Supporting ingredients: Beans add heartiness and fiber, while canned tomatoes create a robust, saucy texture.
  • Equipment needed: Large soup pot or Dutch oven for even cooking and simmering; baking sheet for cornbread croutons.

Preparation:
Chop onions and mince garlic finely. Measure spices and drain beans to prepare for cooking. Preheat oven for cornbread croutons.
Cooking/Baking Process:
Brown meats with onions and garlic over medium heat until cooked through, about 10 minutes. Drain fat if desired. Add liquids, beans, tomatoes, and spices. Simmer uncovered for 30-45 minutes, stirring occasionally until chili thickens and flavors meld.
Finishing Touches:
Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper. Serve chili hot topped with cheese, sour cream, chopped onions, and generous handfuls of homemade cornbread croutons for a satisfying crunch.

note.label: You Must Know
note.content:
• Key technique or temperature for perfect results: Simmer chili uncovered to thicken and concentrate flavors.
  • Common mistake to avoid that could ruin the dish: Don’t skip draining the meat fat if you prefer a leaner chili.
  • Visual or textural cue that indicates it's ready: Look for bubbling and a thick consistency as a sign the chili is ready.
  • Storage and reheating recommendations: Store leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 4 days; reheat gently to preserve texture.

structured_content.content: Sharing this chili with loved ones always brings warmth and joy, reminding me of family dinners filled with laughter and comfort food that feels like a hug in a bowl. The cornbread croutons add a nostalgic twist that sparks conversation and smiles.

Enhance your chili by adding a splash of smoky chipotle in adobo, a dash of cinnamon for warmth, or fresh chopped cilantro for brightness. Swap the beef broth for a splash of beer for deeper complexity. Garnish with diced avocado or a squeeze of lime for a fresh finish.

Serve this chili with a crisp green salad or roasted vegetables for balance. Pair with a cold beer or a robust red wine. For a festive touch, offer toppings like shredded cheese, sour cream, jalapeños, and extra cornbread croutons on the side.

For a vegetarian version, replace meats with extra beans and lentils, and use vegetable broth. Gluten-free eaters can enjoy the chili as is and swap cornbread croutons for gluten-free bread croutons. Spice lovers can increase chili powder or add fresh chilies for heat.

note.label: Pro Tips
note.content:
• Brown meats thoroughly to develop deep flavor through caramelization.
  • Use fresh garlic and onions finely chopped for even flavor distribution.
  • Simmer uncovered to reduce liquid and intensify taste without overcooking beans.
  • Serve with colorful garnishes for an inviting presentation that excites the appetite.

structured_content.content: With this classic chili recipe, you’ll gain confidence in creating a dish that’s both comforting and impressive. Enjoy the process and savor the delicious results that bring warmth and happiness to your table every time.
